abstract.p: Edward W Hayes letter contends new Court TV documentary series Confessions can offer insights into the criminal mind to viewers, contrary to Aug 26 editorial criticizing series as offering prurient material to boost ratings

block.p: An Aug. 26 editorial describes ''Confessions,'' a Court TV documentary series that will broadcast videotaped confessions from actual killers, as an ''appeal to prurience'' that will not offer the context needed to provide insight into criminality.

An Aug. 26 editorial describes ''Confessions,'' a Court TV documentary series that will broadcast videotaped confessions from actual killers, as an ''appeal to prurience'' that will not offer the context needed to provide insight into criminality.

The ''Confessions'' series will show about 40 people talking about why they did the unthinkable. If one wants context for these actions, the serious legal journalism provided by Court TV every day provides context. The confessions will give the viewer insight that probably can't be explained as well as it can be felt.
When I was a young prosecutor, nothing prepared me to be in the room with a killer like the experience of being there. Court TV puts the viewer in that room with the criminal.
EDWARD W. HAYES New York, Aug. 28, 2000
The writer is a lawyer and a part-time anchor for Court TV.
